title: Death of a River Guide
author: Flanagan, Richard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was Richard Flanagan's first novel, and it is quite extraordinary. While the title tells us what the outcome will be from the start, the long appThis was Richard Flanagan's first novel, and it is quite extraordinary. While the title tells us what the outcome will be from the start, the long approach to it builds up the portrait of of Aljaz, his family, and the tragedy he has been running from for 10 years.The book is also a love letter to the wilderness of the Franklin River area, a place of both beauty and terror. Indeed, Flanagan writes beautifully and with grief about Tasmania, especially as it was before the English colonisers came: ... my mind fills with a vision of when the English first arrived and the land was fat and full of trees and game. Had the loss begun at this time? When the English first saw plains so thickly speckled with emu and wallaby dung that it looked as if the heavens must have hailed sleek black turds upon this land, when they first saw the sea and the vast blue Derwent River rainbowed with the vapoury spouts of pods of whales and schools of dolphins swimming beneath. From that time on, each succeeding generation found something new they could quarry to survive. First the emu disappeared, then the tigers, then the many different fishes and seals and whales and their rainbows became rare, then the rivers were stilled under dams, then the trees, and then the scallops and the abalone and the crayfish became few and were in consequence no longer the food of the poor but the waste of the rich.The final 50 pages or so build up and up to a terrible climax, and then finally Aljaz is at peace. Flanagan is one of our major novelists, and I am glad I finally got to read this first work by him....more

title: On A Chinese Screen
author: Maugham, W. Somerset
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: W Somerset Maugham was a wonderful observer of people and places, and of course he was a great writer. This is a book of brief essays about the peopleW Somerset Maugham was a wonderful observer of people and places, and of course he was a great writer. This is a book of brief essays about the people and places he came across while travelling in China after the First World War. The attitudes of the Europeans living in China and exploiting it are predictable but nonetheless appalling. One example is the following:He had been in China for thirty years, and he prided himself on not speaking a word of Chinese. He never went into the Chinese city. His compradore* was Chinese, and some of the clerks, his boys** of course, and the chair coolies; but they were the only Chinese he had anything to do with, and quite enough too."I hate the country, I hate the people," he said. "As soon as I've saved enough money I mean to clear out."* A compradore is a person who acts as an agent for foreign organisations engaged in investment, trade, or economic or political exploitation. (from Wikipedia)**The 'boys' were servants.His descriptions are perfect. The first essay, entitled "The Rising of the Curtain" starts like this:You come to the row of hovels that leads to the gate of the city. They are built of dried mud and so dilapidated that you feel a breath of wind will lay them flat upon the dusty earth from which they have been made. A string of camels, heavily laden, steps warily past you. They wear the disdainful air of profiteers forced to traverse a world in which many people are not so rich as they.I loved that description of the camels.This book isn't as well known as Maugham's fiction, but it is well worth seeking out....more

title: The Infinities
author: Banville, John
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed this book very much indeed. The only other book by Banville that I have read to date was The Untouchable, which was brilliant, and quite difI enjoyed this book very much indeed. The only other book by Banville that I have read to date was The Untouchable, which was brilliant, and quite different from this playful work.The story takes place during the course of one day, and concerns the members of the Godley family. It is narrated by Hermes, and he, Zeus and Pan all have roles to play during that day. It becomes clear quite early on that the setting is in a parallel universe: cars run on brine, yet the postman delivers the mail riding a pony. There are several references to passing trains, including "one of the new-fangled models that run on steam". A mention of the city of Venice refers in passing to the hydrogen-powered breakwater which has saved the city from inundation. Elsewhere there is mention of Oppenheimer "who failed to build the bomb he boasted so much of." Equally intriguing is a reference to Mary Queen of Scots as Gloriana, and her treasonous cousin Elizabeth Tudor, who was beheaded.It is all delicious fun....more

title: The Generations of Men
author: Wright, Judith A.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I found this book rather disappointing. The prose seemed rather pedestrian, which surprised me very much given that Judith Wright was one of our most I found this book rather disappointing. The prose seemed rather pedestrian, which surprised me very much given that Judith Wright was one of our most eminent poets. I also disliked the partly fictional style, almost turning the story of her ancestors into a novel by including various thoughts and feelings which have to be Wright's inventions, even though she had access to diaries and letters of the people of whom she writes.The book was written back in 1959 and Wright went on to be an important activist on the environment and also on the treatment of our First Nations people. It recounts the activities of the settlers including the dispossession of the people whose land they were taking over, the ringbarking of trees in order to grow the grass they wanted for their stock, without any reflection of the terrible damage being inflicted on the people and the land.Only towards the end of the book she imagines her ancestor Albert reflecting on "this whirlwind of destruction" and on how "they had killed Paddy's people, driving them in hundreds over the cliffs of the tableland to die on the rocks below - for spearing cattle, for rebellion against the dominion of money and prosperity."A little later, with Albert still musing, she writes "To forgive oneself - that was the hardest task. Until the white men could recognise and forgive that deep and festering consciousness of guilt in themselves, they would not forgive the blacks for setting it there. The murder would go on - open or concealed - until the blacks were all gone, the whites forever crippled."Wright gives us no indication whatsoever that she has any proof that Albert thought these things. They may be simply her hope that he did have some inkling of what was being done, and indeed continued to be done for many more years, well into the 20th century, as the frontier moved westwards.In the end, the book is about the triumph against the odds of dealing with the challenges of the country to the settlers, who without doubt lived very difficult and often heart-breaking lives of struggle to succeed.Mildly interesting, but not really recommended, especially for those who like their biographies to eschew fictional imaginings, and to look at the subject(s) with a dispassionate eye....more

title: Shakespeare, In Fact
author: Matus, Irvin Leigh
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book was recommended to me by another Goodreads member after I had abandoned a work of fiction masquerading as fact. It was trying to convince thThis book was recommended to me by another Goodreads member after I had abandoned a work of fiction masquerading as fact. It was trying to convince the reader that the works of Shakespeare were really written by the 17th Earl of Oxford, mainly by finding parallels between his life and events in the plays, and of course by telling the reader over and over that Oxford wrote the plays. I had come to the book with an open mind but finished up irritated.This book is brilliant, forensic in detail and utterly crushing in dealing with the various arguments of those who claim that The Man from Stratford could not possibly have written the works of Shakespeare. It is interesting that the book about Oxford completely fails to mention the existence of Matus's book, but hardly surprising!If you are interested in the matter, I recommend this book very highly indeed....more

title: Twilight
author: Frankau, Julia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I picked up this book some time ago when it was published in the "Reclaim Her Name" project, giving back their real names to women who had used a maleI picked up this book some time ago when it was published in the "Reclaim Her Name" project, giving back their real names to women who had used a male pseudonym when publishing books."Twilight" was written early in the 20th century, but is very much in the 19th century Gothic style. It was written as Frankau was dying. Wikipedia tells me:Twilight was a novel completed by Frank Danby on her deathbed, about a female author on her deathbed who is inspired to write about the death of a female author. The character of the ailing Jane Vevaseur is a semi-autobiographical portrayal of Julia Frankau, while her loving sister Eliza Aria is represented by the character of Ella Lovegrove. The title itself is a doubly resonant play on words – the dictum "Work whilst ye have the light" is quoted several times by the narrator, alluding to the fact that she (like Frank Danby) is running out of time; [and there is mention] of what the narrator refers to as "hyoscine", a drug known in its day as "Twilight Sleep". It was all rather feverish and far-fetched, and based on this I'm not surprised that I had never heard of Frank Danby. I don't think I shall bother to look for any other books by her....more

title: Shakespeare by Another Name: The Life of Edward de Vere, Earl of Oxford, the Man Who Was Shakespeare
author: Anderson, Mark*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I abandoned this book about halfway through. I came to it with an open mind, interested to learn more about why a number of people believe that the acI abandoned this book about halfway through. I came to it with an open mind, interested to learn more about why a number of people believe that the actor William Shakespeare was not the author of the plays, but was a "front man" for the 17th Earl of Oxford, Edward de Vere.It starts off well enough, with the author choosing to refer to the actor as Shakspere (one of the many spellings of his name) and to the author as Shake-speare. This falls by the wayside by part way through the second chapter with statements such as:De Vere would pilfer a subplot from "The Supposes", and arguably the entire theme of the play, for "The Taming of the Shrew".Thereafter de Vere is almost always referred to as the author of the plays. Another example is in writing about his travels in Italy:De Vere preserved this entire journey, in reverse, in "Two Gentlement of Verona".After a few hundred pages of this sort of thing, I started to feel I was being bludgeoned into agreeing that Edward de Vere was the author of all of Shakespeare's plays, just because Anderson said so.There is far too much padding out of events that de Vere might have experienced if he was there at the time. There are also pages of supposition of what de Vere might have done during his year on the Continent. It is supposed he travelled to Greece because he wrote to his father-in-law, Lord Cecil, that he would "bestow two or three months to see Constantinople and some part of Greece" when writing about things he wanted to do.So we have him possibly setting out on a 15 day voyage that took him to Ragusa (modern day Dubrovnik), because ships from Venice commonly called in there. Then we read:Walking through this unusual city, de Vere would have been struck by the eclectic influences that defined the coastal metropolis. This usefully links in to "Twelfth Night", making Ragusa the setting of that play because the coast (modern day Croatia) is determined to be the coast of Illyria.If his supposed ship made it as far as Greece, de Vere did not stay there long. As proof of this, Anderson tells us that Shakespeare's plays set in Greece offer little local colour or firsthand knowledge of Greece. And if he went to Greece, he might have gone to Delphi, because this links in to "A Winter's Tale".That's an awful lot of supposition, especially when the only surviving records of de Vere's travels during that summer refer to a visit he made to Palermo in Sicily.After a few hundred pages of this sort of thing, I gave up, looked at the Appendices and found some rather far-fetched explanations for why a number of the great plays only saw the light of day some years after de Vere's death in 1604. (His widow was selling the London house and clearing it out, so this somehow led to the sonnets being published in 1609 and some of the plays to be performed.)This is a book for people who believe without any real proof, that Edward de Vere wrote the entire oeuvre of William Shakespeare. While there are some interesting parallels between de Vere's life and some plot lines in some of the plays, there is absolutely no proof that de Vere wrote the plays and the sonnets.After a bit of investigation, I have decided to get hold of Contested Will by James Shapiro. Hilary Mantel gave it an enthusiastic  in The Guardian when it was published, and that's enough of a recommendation for me. (Anderson dismisses it as A breezy volume that is entertaining to read, "Contested Will" was widely touted as a definitive rout of the non-believers.)So unless you are already sold on the idea of Edward de Vere being Shakespeare, don't bother with this book....more

review: I have to be honest and say that I found a lot of this quite a hard slog - clearly my days as a history student are far behind me! Clark goes through I have to be honest and say that I found a lot of this quite a hard slog - clearly my days as a history student are far behind me! Clark goes through what was happening in various parts of Europe in exhaustive detail and I did get rather bogged down in the details about countries and people with whom I am unfamiliar, such as the Serbians, the various Ministers of the different powers involved at different times in discussions over one crisis or another, etc. The cast of players is huge.The important takeaway from the book really is the incredible complexity of the situation, and the fact that absolutely nothing was black and white in trying to put all the blame for the catastrophe on one or another country or individual. Clark puts it very well indeed in his Conclusion:Do we really need to make the case against a single guilty state, or to rank the states according to their respective share in responsibility for the outbreak of war? In one classical study from the origins literature, Paul Kennedy remarked that it is 'flaccid' to dodge the search for a culprit by blaming all or none of the belligerent states. A stiffer approach, Kennedy implies, ought not to shrink from pointing the finger. The problem with a blame-centred account is not that one may end up blaming the wrong party. It is rather that accounts structured around blame come with built-in assumptions. They tend, firstly, to presume that in conflictual interactions one protagonist must ultimately be right and the other wrong. Were the Serbs wrong to seek to unify Serbdom? Were the Austrians wrong to insist on the independence of Albania? Was one of these enterprises more wrong than the other? The question is meaningless.A large and impressive examination of the many paths to this first great calamity of the 20th century....more

title: The King's Grave: The Search for Richard III
author: PHILIPPA, LANGLEY
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Despite the way this is listed, the book is by two people: Philippa Langley and Michael Jones. Langley was the driving force in getting the excavationDespite the way this is listed, the book is by two people: Philippa Langley and Michael Jones. Langley was the driving force in getting the excavation of Richard's grave done, with a lot of assistance from various people of course. Jones is an historian. They write alternate chapters: Langley about the search for the grave and the work done to establish that the skeleton is indeed that of Richard III, and Jones about the history and the various personalities.I quickly tired of Langley's rather breathless prose and her goosebumps in the car park because she felt she was standing above Richard's grave. The search for Richard's grave is indeed a terrific story, but it's a pity that it wasn't narrated by a more disinterested writer. I have watched the documentaries about the search, so I tended to skip Langley's chapters and read those by Jones.There were no great revelations, but I thought that Jones did a good job of explaining the complexities of the whole mess of the Wars of the Roses, and the family trees helped with keeping on top of who was who, especially as so many of the males were called Edward!The mystery of the "Princes in the Tower" and who was responsible for their deaths will probably never be solved, but I found Jones' arguments persuasive that Richard probably was responsible for ordering their deaths, albeit reluctantly....more

title: Silas Marner
author: Eliot, George
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book really didn't pull me in, though I enjoyed it well enough. I suppose my problem is that I read "Middlemarch" some years ago, and had hoped fThis book really didn't pull me in, though I enjoyed it well enough. I suppose my problem is that I read "Middlemarch" some years ago, and had hoped for some of the complexities of that great book.It is in a way like a fairy tale, with the innocent young man wrongly accused of theft and turned out of the community he knows. From that traumatic event he has lost his religious faith, and his faith in his fellow humans, and becomes a miser whose only comfort is the money he makes as a weaver. That is stolen from him and his world is empty, until a tiny child comes into his home and is the making of him.There are no real surprises in the plot but the book does have some interest in it: for example the way in which industrialisation changes the area where Silas had been a young man so that it was almost unrecognisable to him; and the insufferable assumption of the local squire and his wife that life with them would be so much better for Eppie than her life with Silas.Two and a half stars, rounded up to three....more

title: The Fortune of War        (Aubrey & Maturin, #6)
author: O'Brian, Patrick
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a delight to enjoy another adventure with Stephen Maturin and Jack Aubrey. Patrick O'Brian writes so well, and with such knowledge of the period,What a delight to enjoy another adventure with Stephen Maturin and Jack Aubrey. Patrick O'Brian writes so well, and with such knowledge of the period, the ships and the psychology of his characters, that the reader knows he or she can trust his every word. When you add to that the moments that caused me, at least, to laugh out loud even in the midst of a moment of tense escape, then the book moves effortlessly from being four stars to five. This passage in particular was hilarious:'Boat your oars,’ said Jack. ‘Clap on to the halliard – no, the halliard. God’s death – haul away. Bear a hand, Stephen. Belay. Catch a couple of turns round the kevel – the kevel.’The scow gave a violent lurch. Jack dropped all, scrambled forward, caught two turns round the kevel and slid back to the tiller. The sail filled, he brought the wind a little abaft the beam, and the scow headed out to sea.‘You are cursed snappish tonight, Jack,’ said Stephen. ‘How do you expect me to understand your altumal cant, without pondering on it? I do not expect you to understand medical jargon, without giving you time to consider the etymology, for all love.’‘Not to know the odds between a halliard and a sheet, after all these years at sea: it passes human understanding,’ said Jack.‘You are a reasonably civil, complaisant creature on dry land,’ said Stephen, ‘but the moment you are afloat you become pragmatical and absolute, a bashaw – do this, do that, gluppit the prawling strangles, there – no longer a social being at all. It is no doubt the effect of the long-continued habit of command; but it cannot be considered amiable.’Wonderful stuff....more

title: JUSTICE GAME, THE
author: Robertson, Geoffrey
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: At times very witty and amusing, and at others quite horrifying as Robertson details some of the many cases in which he has defended people against apAt times very witty and amusing, and at others quite horrifying as Robertson details some of the many cases in which he has defended people against apparently hopeless odds. Often, these people are on Legal Aid - he is not just in it for the money by any means. He has acted as an observer for Amnesty International in some of the murkier parts of the world and over decades has tried to ensure that justice is done. In one of the cases, brought in 1985 against a bookshop called Gay's the Word, "Operation Tiger" was an exercise which over 18 months was concerned with the importation of "indecent" books. The proprietors opted for public commital proceedings, in order to expose the warped priorities of a customs service which devoted more of its resources to impounding literature than to seizing cocaine.He then recounts the moment when  (i)n an atmosphere where everyone was enjoying the prosecution discomfort, I made three mistakes in the course of asking one question in cross-examination. I played to the gallery; I deployed sarcasm, the lowest form of wit; and I asked a question to which I did not know the answer. Pointing an accusing finger at the young customs officer who had code-named the operation, I declaimed, "You called this operation 'Tiger', did you not, because that name was redolent of swaggering machismo?" The officer replied, "Well, no sir. Actually, I named it after my cat."Such laugh-out-loud moments help bring needed lightness to a book which often deals with very dark matters indeed, not least those caused by the UK government of the day being prepared to have innocent parties accused of wrongdoing in order to cover up its own criminal behaviour. One of the worst of these is called UK Ltd: The Matrix Churchill Trial, and it makes for chilling reading. Plus ça change ...Highly recommended....more

title: The Secret Chord
author: Brooks, Geraldine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't know - maybe historical fiction is just not my thing any more. I enjoyed this well enough, but I had hoped to enjoy it more. Every so often BrI don't know - maybe historical fiction is just not my thing any more. I enjoyed this well enough, but I had hoped to enjoy it more. Every so often Brooks jerked me out of the story with something which seemed anachronistic.One example was a passing reference by the narrator, the prophet Natan, to migrating birds. Now, the ancient Greeks did have some idea of bird migration, but did the ancient tribes of the area we now call Israel, back in about 1000 BCE? Maybe they did, but it made me stop because I rather doubt it.Far more out of its time was a reference to King David's music-making: His own compositions of that time were mighty things that reflected the building of the city, constructed of solid, symmetrical sounds, perfect fifths stacked one atop the other like the confident edifices of a powerful and joyous king.Perfect fifths??? The king's compositions had leap-frogged many centuries to the 17th, when modal music gave way to the modern system of major and minor scales and the rules of harmony, of which the perfect fifth is an important part.Okay - these things don't matter in the main telling of the story, but if they jerk the reader out of the period of King David into more modern times, then that bothers me, and of course makes me wonder about other possible inaccuracies in the telling of the tale. Don't editors pick these things up any more? Or am I just being too picky?Overall I enjoyed it well enough, but not as much as I had hoped to do....more

title: Pigeon Pie
author: Mitford, Nancy
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Sadly, the timing of publication of this delicious book was wrong. Mitford had written it in the very early stage of World War II, the "phony war" as Sadly, the timing of publication of this delicious book was wrong. Mitford had written it in the very early stage of World War II, the "phony war" as it was called, but it was published in 1940 when the war had become very real and grim indeed, so that it sank almost without trace.She pokes fun at the upper class (Lady Sophia is wonderfully dense), politics, peculiar religious groups and spy stories. Fortunately everything comes right "in the last reel" despite some anxious moments.Here is a taste of her witty style:Fred and Ned were very partial to Lady Beech. She was the only link they had with culture, and Fred and Ned were by no means so insensible to things of the mind as they appeared to be. At school and at Oxford they had been clever boys with literary gifts and a passion for the humanities; it was only their too early excursion into politics which had reduced their intellectual capacity once more to that of the private school.Absolutely delightful. ...more

review: Three and a half stars, rounded up to four. Nancy Mitford's mockery of the British fascists is good fun, and understandably was the cause of serious fThree and a half stars, rounded up to four. Nancy Mitford's mockery of the British fascists is good fun, and understandably was the cause of serious family rifts, given that one of her sisters married Sir Oswald Mosley, who founded and led the British Union of Fascists and another who was enamoured of Hitler.Mitford's fascists are called Social Unionists, and are known as the Union Jackshirts, because their uniform is, as you might guess, a shirt made from a Union Jack. I particularly liked their hymn, sung to the tune of "Onward Christian Soldiers":Onward, Union JackshirtsFight for England's fameFight and die for England,Saving her from shame.When foreigners make grimaces,Stamp them in the mud,Jump upon their faces,Cover them with blood.Onward, Union Jackshirts ... etc.Alongside all this is the story of two young men in search of heiresses to marry, two young women who call themselves Miss Smith and Miss Jones, a married woman who fancies herself to be the heroine of a Ruritanian romance, and various other characters, some more sensible than others.Wickedly entertaining....more

title: From the Edge: Australia's Lost Histories
author: McKenna, Mark
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This is such an interesting and thought-provoking book, with four little-known stories of interactions between First Nations people and the British peThis is such an interesting and thought-provoking book, with four little-known stories of interactions between First Nations people and the British people who were either passing through or seeking to settle in their lands. The first story of an incredible trek from the coast of Victoria all the way to Sydney by a group of shipwrecked men is absolutely gripping. They only did this with the help of the many Indigenous people through whose country they were passing, and it is heartbreaking to read how quickly the story was changed by people including the Governor of New South Wales, to emphasise the one bad experience the men had in order to turn this into a story of brave white men surviving the savages.As Mark McKenna says at the end of the book: For any of us to develop a truly honest and informed historical consciousness in Australia requires a double-act: to hold both the violent dispossession of Indigenous Australians and the steady emergence of a society built on equality, democracy and freedom from racial discrimination in our imagination at the same time, and to do so by hearing both the Indigenous and non-Indigenous perspectives.We need more books about our history like this one....more

review: I found some of the letters more interesting than others: those where du Maurier wrote to her friend about work on one or other of her books, and whatI found some of the letters more interesting than others: those where du Maurier wrote to her friend about work on one or other of her books, and what was clearly a disappointment in not being taken seriously as a writer because her books were so popular. That snobbery that says if a lot of people enjoy a book means that it cannot be considered literary seems ridiculous to me. This comment about The Scapegoat made me smile:So it is certainly going to be off to a good start in America, but I am sure to have sniffs and jeers in this country, especially if old Victor [Gollancz, her publisher] does those irritating adverts about it selling a lot before it is even published, which I am sure makes critics despise me more than ever. I am sure if he said, ‘This book has sold no copies, and nobody who has looked at it can understand a word,’ the critics would be nice, for once!This is not a book to read through from beginning to end without interruption, any more than one reads letters from a friend one after the other. I enjoyed reading just a few letters at a time. I also enjoyed the sections in which Oriel Malet, to whom the letters were addressed, expanded on some of the people or events to which du Maurier referred.Probably of interest only to people who have read and enjoyed du Maurier's many books....more

title: Her Mother's Daughter: A Memoir
author: Wheatley, Nadia
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read and admired Nadia Wheatley's biography of Charmian Clift some years ago, so when I heard her discussing that book and this one in a radio progrI read and admired Nadia Wheatley's biography of Charmian Clift some years ago, so when I heard her discussing that book and this one in a radio programme, I went looking for this memoir of her mother. What I have just finished reading is a loving reconstruction of the life of Wheatley's mother, who died when Wheatley was only eight years old. The book is much more than just a study of her mother Neen: it is about the attitudes towards women in Australia before and after the Second World War, about her mother's war service and post war work with displaced persons in Germany. And then it is about her father, his sadistic treatment of his wife and daughter, and the grim reality of Wheatley's life after her mother died.This is not a "misery memoir", but a fine work of research, as well as a loving tribute, and a story of survival against the odds....more

review: What a strangely disappointing book. Perry writes well and I enjoyed her previous novel, The Essex Serpent. This one was more of a plod and the centraWhat a strangely disappointing book. Perry writes well and I enjoyed her previous novel, The Essex Serpent. This one was more of a plod and the central character was so busy martyring herself for something she had done 20 years ago, that she became irritating. We do finally learn what her crime was and yes, it was despicable. She could have done something about it to save another from suffering her punishment, and didn't. I found the reaction of her friends, along the lines of "Oh well, what's done is done" inexplicable. The ending was also pretty unbelievable, though I did like the little twist from the narrator on the final page. The best parts were the descriptions of some of the atrocious things which humans do to each other, the most memorable being one concerning the Armenian genocide by the Turks. I don't mean that these were enjoyable, but that they were powerfully written, and at those moments the book became gripping.I'm glad I didn't pay full price for this one, but got it on special!...more

review: Jane Austen managed to create her glorious, witty books in 200 or so pages each. Janice Hadlow took 650 pages trying to emulate Austen's style by borrJane Austen managed to create her glorious, witty books in 200 or so pages each. Janice Hadlow took 650 pages trying to emulate Austen's style by borrowing many of her turns of phrase, imagining the characters from Pride and Prejudice from another angle by making Mary Bennet the central character of her tale.Not very much happens, but we are told about it in microscopic detail. And of course Mary finds herself and finds true love. While the tone is mostly a reasonable facsimile of Austen's there are occasional glitches: describing the children of Mary's aunt and uncle Gardiner as her nieces and nephews, rather than her cousins, is one silly mistake. Talk of swapping seats rather jarred, as did one character saying We must crack on. Reference to the great lake at Windermere seems to be a modern error that would not have been made in the early 19th century.I really must stop reading books that people tell me I shall enjoy when my instinct tells me that I won't!...more

He became the country's Prime Minister a year after this study was written. He lost that position after a couple of years of mayhem, and lost his parliamentary seat (to an excellent Independent MP) a few years later.David Marr writes so well and gave us a balanced and rounded portrait of the man. title: A Week in September: A Story of Enduring Love from the Burma Railway
author: Rees, Peter
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have a personal link to this book, having for many years sung in a choir conducted by Doug Heywood, the younger son of Scott Heywood. It is such a sI have a personal link to this book, having for many years sung in a choir conducted by Doug Heywood, the younger son of Scott Heywood. It is such a sad story of survival against the odds over years of brutal POW camps, only to die in the last days before the Japanese surrender. The same thing happened to my husband's uncle. The anguish of the families at home waiting for news of their men, the elation when the war ended, and then the dreadful news of the death after so many year of waiting. On top of that was the attitude of the time which basically told the bereaved just to get on with life, with no counselling in how to deal with the trauma.This isn't great literature by any means, but it is a sad and moving story. My main criticism of the book is that it did not need the comparisons with the experiences of Viktor Frankl to validate Scott's attitude and ability to cope with the situation, while helping his fellow sufferers. His innate decency, and the respect and affection in which he was held by his comrades, are more than enough. ...more

review: An enjoyable and dramatic story, interesting to read because it deals with the early part of the French Revolution in the provinces rather than in ParAn enjoyable and dramatic story, interesting to read because it deals with the early part of the French Revolution in the provinces rather than in Paris. The narrator is an aristocrat who has his heart in the right place in terms of his treatment of people, though of course he still has the attitudes and unthinking assumptions of superiority of his class and time. His flaws make him believable, and we experience with him the chaos and confusion which must have been overwhelming.Weyman handles his plot well, and while the way in which our hero manages to meet the right people at the right time is quite amazing good luck, the story gallops along and sweeps the reader along with it.A solid three stars....more

title: Bird Bonds
author: Kaplan, Gisela
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Gisela Kaplan is a national treasure, and her books on birds and their behaviour are essential reading for anyone who wants to understand something abGisela Kaplan is a national treasure, and her books on birds and their behaviour are essential reading for anyone who wants to understand something about what makes them tick.I find her interpretation of the ways in which birds interact totally convincing. She has spent her life observing birds scientifically, but also with love and admiration. In her Epilogue, she says:... the book has taken the risky step of deliberately comparing the ability of humans and birds to form bonds and pursuing some of the arguments that are usually made in human psychology and human neuroscience to test whether emotional bonds and strong attachments would even be biologically conceivable. ...It is now time to ... concede that the class of birds may not just have vocal learning in common with humans but, in some highly evolved species, also the emotional ability for selective and enduring attachment to others. We usually call it love, but it is rather 'pragma', based on attachment and commitment, and making possible empathy and even the controversial 'altruism'.Highly recommended to anyone with an interest in birds, especially the birds of Australia....more

review: A series of thoughtful, measured and often very sad essays in which Grant meditates on what it means to be an Australian, the ongoing pain of our FirsA series of thoughtful, measured and often very sad essays in which Grant meditates on what it means to be an Australian, the ongoing pain of our First Nations, and how we might find a way forward together:We need to write a new declaration: a Declaration of Country. It does not speak only to Indigenous people, it does not speak to Britain or the homelands of those migrants who have made their way to these shores. It speaks first to this land, this place here before any human footprint, this place that is our home.A nation is not just a set of laws. A nation is above all a story, a never-ending story of us. It is the story of a land steeped in time, awaiting people from many other lands, who in time will call themselves Australians.Stan Grant is a national treasure....more

review: Martin Luther King, Jr was murdered in 1968. It is heartbreaking to think that most of the things he wrote and spoke about as needing to happen to briMartin Luther King, Jr was murdered in 1968. title: Mantel Pieces: Royal Bodies and Other Writing from the London Review of Books
author: Mantel, Hilary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I always enjoy reading Hilary Mantel, whether it is her fiction or her essays and book s. Her words are for the most part serious, which is why I always enjoy reading Hilary Mantel, whether it is her fiction or her essays and book s. Her words are for the most part serious, which is why the sly jokes she inserts every so often are all the more enjoyable. As a sample, two from the same essay ing a book on Margaret Pole, a member of the Plantagenet family:Susan Higginbotham's carefully written book comes with a misleading cover puff: 'At last, a biography of one of the most fascinating women of the Tudor period', who has 'too long been overlooked'. But Margaret Pole, one of the great magnates of Tudor England, is not overlooked. In "The King's Curse" (2014) she was ground up by the great fictionalising machine that is Philippa Gregory ...And in writing about aristocratic women who were able to exert independence once they were widowed:As widows, or as deputies to living husbands, they handled complex legal and financial affairs with aplomb, while assenting - outwardly at least - to their status as irrational and inferior beings. Gaily agreeing that the chief female virtues are meekness and self-effacement, they managed estates, signed off accounts, bought wardships and brokered marriage settlements, all the while keeping up a steady output of needlework.The only problem with this book is that it involves s of several books that I now want to read, as if I didn't have more than enough books on my TBR list already!A delightful book for dipping into between other activities....more

title: Talking to My Country
author: Grant, Stan
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Stan Grant is a very fine journalist - one of our best. He writes clearly and engagingly, and always with compassion. He also happens to be an indigenStan Grant is a very fine journalist - one of our best. He writes clearly and engagingly, and always with compassion. He also happens to be an indigenous Australian, so he knows first hand the grief and pain of our First Nations people.I read a couple of s here in Goodreads which describe this as an angry book. I didn't feel any anger from him, but I did feel his grief and despair. One example was his description of his feelings of exclusion as he sat in the stadium for the opening ceremony of the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney:I am from a people with a heritage deeper than any on show before me that evening. We were the first seafarers. We found a home in an isolated continent cut off from the great land bridge to Africa. We are the oldest uninterrupted civilisation on earth. Yet, on this night we were nowhere. This was Australia's night under Australia's flag. The flag carried in its corner the Union Jack of Britain, an enduring symbol of our dispossession. The flag had excluded us, for so many years denying our citizenship. This was what colonisation meant and I had never felt it so deeply - I had never felt so powerless - as I did that night.A little further on in the book he writes about the ongoing effects of racism and dispossession, and how that pain and suffering became printed on my DNA. Doctors talk about epigenetic inheritance: the experiences of parents and grandparents passed directly to their offspring. Some families carry genetic illness, passed down through the generations. My people inherit the loss of our country. It has proven as incurable and potentially lethal as any cancer.Finally, this brought me close to tears:Racism isn't killing the Australian dream. The Australian dream was founded on racism. From the first time a British flag was planted in this soil, the rules have been different for us. A convict could come in chains and die free, a rich man. But British law condemned us to a longer sentence.This book should be a set text for every school in the country, and kept there until our future generations learn how to treat our First Nations with honour and respect. They have the generosity to share their ancient culture with all Australians: we need to appreciate the value of that gift....more

review: I read "The Radiant Way" a great many years ago, and remember nothing about it. I have never read the second book in the trilogy, so came to this finaI read "The Radiant Way" a great many years ago, and remember nothing about it. I have never read the second book in the trilogy, so came to this final volume without any real prior knowledge of the characters in it.I enjoyed it well enough, but probably not enough to make me want to go back and read the first two volumes of the trilogy. There were some powerful passages in it, mostly in connection with Cambodia and the refugees from the horrors visited upon that tragic country by Pol Pot. The following seemed to sum up what little I know of the terrible situation in which so many people in refugee camps must find themselves:She had watched others around her deal with their memories in this way, and in others. Some, like her daughter Sok Sita, had lost their wits. Some had cauterized the past with rage, and lived off anger and hatred. Some had been arrested as by a flow of burning lava in postures of bowed submission, of cowed despair: and now crawled around, bent and deformed. Some of the young fed off film-star dreams of escape. Playing ping-pong, they chattered of visas and papers that would never come. Some plotted revenge. Some went back across the border to join the resistance. Some lived for the moment, learning camp ways, learning to wheedle and exploit and profit, to scavenge and trade. Even here, there were objects to sell and recycle, there were unexplained arrivals of snakeskin and pig meat and musical instruments. Of late, a new supply of small carvings had begun to appear on the market. A lizard, a fish, a flower, a crocodile: antique or fake, who cared? They fetched a price....more

review: Barbara Pym knew all about the lonely lives that many people lead. I found it quite a dark story, as the four main characters live their narrow lives,Barbara Pym knew all about the lonely lives that many people lead. I found it quite a dark story, as the four main characters live their narrow lives, apparently unable to find anything to enrich them in terms of involvement in activities with or without other people.All they seem to have in their lives, apart from Edwin who moves from one church to another, is their work. The work itself seems to be utterly meaningless and is clearly unimportant. When the two women both retire on the same day, they are not replaced, but the men don't seem to have any extra work to do. Marcia spirals downward once the routine of work is removed. Letty does grow and starts to change, and I did like the way in which Pym left us at the end with hope that this would continue:"... it made one realise that life still held infinite possibilities for change."...more

review: Trollope must have been paid by the word when he wrote this book, or else he needed a good editor. Trimmed down to about a third of its length, it wouTrollope must have been paid by the word when he wrote this book, or else he needed a good editor. Trimmed down to about a third of its length, it would have been far more enjoyable in my opinion. I realise this is probably heresy to true devotees of Trollope, but it was a big disappointment. I am working my way slowly through the Chronicles of Barsetshire, and I do hope that the final book in the series is better than this one.Apart from his verbosity, Trollope surprised me with a truly nauseating small child, whose appearance was mercifully brief. After a comment by Adolphus Crosbie that if he received any more commiseration over a black eye he would lie down and die, he was asked by his future nephew:"Shall 'oo die Uncle Dolphus, 'cause 'oo've got a bad eye?"Perhaps the Victorians weren't good at writing small children because they didn't actually have much to do with them. I have loved a number of Trollope's books, but this isn't one of them! 2.5 stars....more

title: Suite Française
author: Némirovsky, Irène
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What an extraordinary book this is, and the story of its rediscovery after decades is also extraordinary. Handwritten in a notebook, it is really a fiWhat an extraordinary book this is, and the story of its rediscovery after decades is also extraordinary. Handwritten in a notebook, it is really a first draft of the first two books of a planned five part work depicting life in France under occupation during the Second World War. The tragedy of Irène Némirovsky's deportation from France and her murder in Auschwitz in August 1942 meant this never came to pass. There are errors here and there in the book, which no doubt would have been corrected had she been able to complete the work. At the same time, there is a sense of the lived experience which is immediate and gripping.The descriptions in the first book of the chaos and confusion as people fled Paris with the approach of the Nazis are terrifying. The apparent peace of a village under occupation in the second book is fascinating. On the surface there were quite friendly relations between the villagers and the German soldiers living among them. At the same time there was the suspicion that despite kindness to the children and friendly overtures to the adults, "... if tomorrow he was given the order, he'd arrest me, he'd kill me with his own hands without thinking twice? War ... yes, everyone knows what war is like. But occupation is more terrible in a way, because people get used to each other. We tell ourselves, 'They're just like us, after all,' but they're not at all the same. We're two different species, irreconcilable, enemies forever."Highly recommended....more

title: Excellent Women
author: Pym, Barbara
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is a comedy, and yet I found a sadness in the narrow life of the narrator, Mildred. Set in the early 1950s, the difficulties of the post-warThis book is a comedy, and yet I found a sadness in the narrow life of the narrator, Mildred. Set in the early 1950s, the difficulties of the post-war years in Britain add to the limited life led by a single woman whose only social contacts are with other members of her church congregation. Her closest friends are the vicar and his sister, Julian and Winifred. Her horizons are broadened when a married couple move into the flat below hers, and their lives spill over into hers.Much of the comedy comes with Mildred's wry thoughts about herself and others. At one point, Winifred says of Mildred to her brother:"You know Mildred would never do anything wrong or foolish."I reflected a little sadly that this was only too true and hoped I did not appear too much that kind of person to others. Virtue is an excellent thing and we should all strive after it, but it can sometimes be a litle depressing.Later, out to a restaurant meal with the couple, Rocky and Helena, and Helena's anthropologist colleague Everard, she has to deal for the first time with spaghetti and had to be shown how to twist it around her fork. "I found it very difficult to manage and it made conversation quite impossible. Perhaps long spaghetti is the kind of thing that ought to be eaten quite alone with nobody to watch one's struggles. Surely many a romance must have been nipped in the bud by sitting opposite somebody eating spaghetti?"At the end, we are left with the possibility that she may end up marrying Everard, but there is no certainty about this, because like most of the other characters in the book, he looks upon her as an "excellent woman" who is there only to help others, and needs nothing in return....more

review: It is a curious experience to start a book expecting it to be a light-hearted comedy, and find that in fact it is about the miseries of a love betweenIt is a curious experience to start a book expecting it to be a light-hearted comedy, and find that in fact it is about the miseries of a love between an unhappily married woman and a divorced man. It is said to be semi-autobiographical, and much of it does ring true.Even allowing for the attitudes of the time in which it was written, I did find it startling that a woman in her thirties would think to herself about her husband that "one needed a master", and another woman several years younger would think her husband might someday "give her the beating she so richly deserved". When meeting the central character (whom we must presume to be standing for Thirkell herself) when she was aged about 20, an older woman had thought that "... life would go hard with the child unless she married a man who could worship her and govern her at the same time." Crikey!There are flashes of Thirkell's wit here and there. The best one for me was a reference to "an exhibition of Obscure and Justly Neglected Copyists of the Early Eighteenth Century ... I hear it has points of interest." People must have been queuing up to get in!Somehow, Thirkell managed to pull herself together after getting this book out of her system, and went on to write the sparkling "High Rising", with a very different version of herself in the author Laura Morland.2 stars....more

review: A book I have meant to read for many years. A warning in terms of the damage that humans are doing to the planet, and against hubris. In Greek tragedy, to equate oneself with the gods was to bring down their wrath and destruction.The book was first published in 1971, and its prescience in terms of climate change and its damage to life in the future, is remarkable. Few of us were thinking about this back then, and were blissfully unaware of the crisis in the making.If given the ability to improve the situation in a moment, would we do it? If one man could create such a supposed Utopia, what would that mean for the lives of those swept aside to achieve it?A thought-provoking book....more

title: Vesper Flights
author: Macdonald, Helen
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: What a perfect, beautiful book with which to finish the year. Helen Macdonald, author of the justly famous H is for Hawk has collected in this book esWhat a perfect, beautiful book with which to finish the year. Helen Macdonald, author of the justly famous H is for Hawk has collected in this book essays written for various publications over the last few years. She writes about the natural world, and the damage we humans are doing to it. She feels the need to bear witness to what is changing, and what we have lost already in our relentless march of so-called progress. To give a taste of her writing, this is the final part of the last essay, What Animals Taught Me:Feeling the need for air, I sit on my back doorstep and see a rook, a sociable species of European crow, flying low towards my house through greying evening air. Straight away I use the trick I learned as a child, and all my difficult emotions lessen as I imagine how the press of cooling air might feel against its wings. But my deepest relief doesn’t come from imagining I can feel what the rook feels, know what the rook knows – instead, it’s slow delight in knowing I cannot. These days I take emotional solace from knowing that animals are not like me, that their lives are not about us at all. The house it’s flying over has meaning for both of us. To me it is home; to the rook? A waypoint on a journey, a collection of tiles and slopes, useful as a perch, or a thing to drop walnuts on in autumn to make them shatter and let it winkle out the flesh inside. But there is something else. As it passes overhead, the rook tilts its head to regard me briefly before flying on. And with that glance I feel a prickling in my skin that runs down my spine, my sense of place shifts, and the world is enlarged. The rook and I have shared no purpose. We noticed each other, is all. When I looked at the rook and the rook looked at me, I became a feature of its world as much as it became a feature of mine. Our separate lives coincided, and all my self-absorbed anxiety vanished in that one fugitive moment, when a bird in the sky on its way somewhere else sent a glance across the divide and stitched me back into a world where both of us have equal billing.I loved this book, and cannot recommend it too highly....more

review: A great many years ago, I read a book of essays called “If it had Happened Otherwise”, which took various historical events and then examined what theA great many years ago, I read a book of essays called “If it had Happened Otherwise”, which took various historical events and then examined what the outcomes might have been if a key factor had changed. I have loved this sort of writing ever since. Christopher Priest takes as his historical event the flight of Rudolf Hess to Scotland to try to bring about a peace treaty between Germany and Great Britain.His way into this is through the lives of identical twins Jack and Joe Sawyer. But this is not a straightforward different history - there are many versions of the lives of these two young men. We are in the realm of quantum mechanics and parallel universes.The book is brilliant, intriguing and utterly absorbing. I loved it. One of the best books of the year for me....more

review: A tale told by many different people, including a Tasmanian Aboriginal, who reminds us of the deep tragedy of what colonisation did to the indigenous A tale told by many different people, including a Tasmanian Aboriginal, who reminds us of the deep tragedy of what colonisation did to the indigenous people of Australia.On the surface, there is much to amuse the reader: a favourite moment early in the book was when a suggestion was made that wallabies could be used as pack animals. But despite the adventures of a group of Manx smugglers who finish up taking as passengers an ill-assorted group of people who are seeking the Garden of Eden in Tasmania, there is the huge sadness of what was done to the people for whom their world really was the Garden of Eden.I found Kneale's telling of the collision of these disparate groups interesting, though possibly some of the voices were redundant and the information could have been given in other ways. review: Somehow this book sounded as if it would be more gripping than it was. I kept finding other things to do, rather wanting to get back to reading it.TheSomehow this book sounded as if it would be more gripping than it was. I kept finding other things to do, rather wanting to get back to reading it.The story has disasters both natural and man-made, murder, incest, war, history. The narrator, Tom Crick, is a history teacher who starts telling his class his own family history rather than sticking to the curriculum. He weaves back and forth between his childhood and the more distant past. For me it didn't work, but clearly many others liked the book very much.I did like this passage:"History begins only at the point where things go wrong; history is born only with trouble, with perplexity, with regret. So that hard on the heels of the word Why comes the sly and wistful word If. If it had not been for ... If only ... Were it not ... Those useless Ifs of history. And, constantly impeding, deflecting, distracting the backward searchings of the question why, looms this other form of retrogression: If only we could have it back. A New Beginning. If only we could return ..."...more

review: An interesting book to read as a product of its time, and of course also a product of the extremely right wing values and attitudes of Evelyn Waugh. TAn interesting book to read as a product of its time, and of course also a product of the extremely right wing values and attitudes of Evelyn Waugh. The tone is set before the story starts, with a Preface which Waugh wrote in 1962. Its final paragraph reads:"Thirty years ago it seemed an anachronism that any part of Africa should be independent of European administration. History has not followed what then seemed its natural course."However, Waugh's disdain is not confined to "the natives". His portrayal of the British envoy, his family and assorted staff is funny, as is the spying on the British by the French envoy and some splendid conspiracy theories he concocts.A curious book: worth reading as part of a project to read all of Waugh's books, but probably not one I would want to revisit....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very silly, and very enjoyable to read during these dark days. Thirkell is delightful in her observations of the exploits of children. I laughed out lVery silly, and very enjoyable to read during these dark days. Thirkell is delightful in her observations of the exploits of children. I laughed out loud at this one, as part of the description of the nursery used by several generations of the same family in their country home:"A large doll's house stood over by the window, its once elegant contents a mere jumble of wreckage. This regrettable mishap had taken place when David was the spoilt baby. He had decided that his friend the kitchen cat wantedt to be introduced to the joys of domestic life on a small scale. He therefore formed the habit of fetching George, all unwilling, from the kitchen, carrying him upstairs with his arms tightly clasped under George's front legs, while George's furious hind legs clawed the air in vain for support. He would then push George in at the front door and shut it behind him. George, much agitated, would worm his way up the staircase and squeeze his body into each room in turn, vainly seeking some mode of exit. Then David discovered that if he opened the windows George, who was just too large to get through them, would in his frenzy paw all the smaller articles of furniture out of the window and then sit, crossly regarding his kind young benefactor, his large sullen face far larger than the window at which it appeared. The dolls's house had also at various times been used as a home for mice and silkworms, and was rapidly qualifying for demolition under a slum clearance scheme."...more

title: Bring Up the Bodies        (Thomas Cromwell, #2)
author: Mantel, Hilary
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: "What is the nature of the border between truth and lies? It is permeable and blurred because it is planted thick with rumour, confabulation, misunder"What is the nature of the border between truth and lies? It is permeable and blurred because it is planted thick with rumour, confabulation, misunderstandings and twisted tales. Truth can break the gates down, truth can howl in the street; unless truth is pleasing, personable, and easy to like, she is condemned to stay whimpering at the back door."I didn't enjoy this volume of Mantel's trilogy as much as I enjoyed "Wolf Hall", but that's because I thought the latter was brilliant indeed. One of the things I really liked about the first volume was its immediacy - calling Thomas Cromwell "he" gave the feeling we were not quite inside his head, but certainly looking over his shoulder. Perhaps many people found this confusing, because Mantel has unfortunately felt the need to explain this by writing quite frequently "he, Thomas Cromwell". I found this irritating, but maybe others found it helpful when there were several people together.The book covers only nine months, but what a tumultuous time it was from September 1535 to the summer of 1536. Did Cromwell actually believe that Anne Boleyn was guilty of adultery and incest, or was he just doing what Henry wanted to remove her? We don't know. Truth is left whimpering at the back door indeed. ...more

title: Rereadings: Seventeen Writers Revisit Books They Love
author: Fadiman, Anne
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A series of essays by a number of different writers in which each discusses a book read in childhood or adolescence, and reread recently in maturity. A series of essays by a number of different writers in which each discusses a book read in childhood or adolescence, and reread recently in maturity. I knew only some of the books being discussed, so naturally found those essays of more interest.However, there were a number of good moments to be enjoyed even in a discussion of a book and author unknown to me. I liked this comment:"As children, we crossed wide-eyed and trusting into the writer's world; as adults, we invite the writer into ours and hold him accountable for how he behaves there." (Arthur Krystal, "Kid Roberts and Me".)I loved the essay by Diana Kappel Smith titled "My Life with a Field Guide" where she wrote about her copy of "Field Guide to Wildflowers of Northeastern and North-Central North America", which started her on the path to becoming a nature writer and illustrator. "It is in smithereens now and buckled by damp, held together with a trio of rubber bands. In spite of its copious annotations and cross-references, I tend to use a newer model, though I do take the old one along from time to time, just to let it smell the Diapensia, so to speak, much as I might take an arthritic family dog for a ramble, out of kindness, and because of happy memories of adventurous times when both of us were less marked up."Luc Sante in "A Companion of the Prophet" wrote about his relationship with Arthur Rimbaud. He made me laugh out loud with this:"At some point before adolescence, I had decided to become a child prodigy ..."An enjoyable collection, with an interesting Foreword: On Rereading by Anne Fadiman. The essays all come from "The American Scholar", a literary quarterly. Some years ago, it was her decision as editor of the quarterly to "open the books section with an essay not on reading something new but on rereading something old"....more

title: The Bookshop
author: Fitzgerald, Penelope
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: My first Penelope Fitzgerald, and definitely not my last. A beautifully written story, on the surface apparently insubstantial, but one that stays witMy first Penelope Fitzgerald, and definitely not my last. A beautifully written story, on the surface apparently insubstantial, but one that stays with me. It has a melancholy feel to it, although there are certainly some very funny passages in it.It is a book about isolation, loneliness and defeat. It is also about the utter ruthlessness of a narcissist who sees the action of opening a bookshop as a challenge to her role as "the natural patroness of all public activities in Hardborough". Violet Gamart is out to destroy Florence Green, and Florence is no match for her."She blinded herself, in short, by pretending for a while that human beings are not divided into exterminators and exterminatees, with the former, at any given moment, predominating. Will-power is useless without a sense of direction. Hers was at such a low ebb that it no longer gave her the instructions for survival."There are some lovely descriptions of the landscape and the birdlife to be seen, and a real sense of the power of the sea encroaching always on the land and the structures raised by humans: the river became unnavigable, the swing bridge fell in, the sea wall caved in, and a housing estate built on a cliff top was tumbling into the sea before anyone had moved into it.Violet Gamart is as inexorable and as ruthless as the sea, sweeping aside anything and anyone in her way. She is a malevolent version of E F Benson's gloriously funny Lucia Lucas.A sad book, but so well done. 4.5 stars....more

title: Crump Folk Going Home
author: Holme, Constance
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I was inspired to dig out my copy of this book (inherited from my mother, and last read in my teens) because I was somehow reminded of parts of it whiI was inspired to dig out my copy of this book (inherited from my mother, and last read in my teens) because I was somehow reminded of parts of it while reading James Rebanks' "The Shepherd's Life", which describes his life and work as a sheep farmer in Cumbria.My memory had not played me false, as I found that Holme's book is set in Westmorland back in 1913 (the year of publication of this, her first novel). This county, along with Cumberland, became Cumbria in 1974 and contains The Lake District.The book is interesting to read because of the society it depicts in that time of relative innocence just before the start of the Great War, the attitudes, especially in terms of the place of women in that society, the class divisions, and so on. It verges on melodrama at times, but its saving grace is a wonderful passage near the beginning of the book describing a Sheepdog Trial, and in particular a man working with a dog he has just rescued from its drunken and abusive owner. I wished she had spent more of the book on this man, Anthony Dixon, rather than on some of the "toffs".I shall dip into Holme's other books from time to time to see how her writing matured over the years. ...more

title: The Shepherd's Life: A People's History of the Lake District
author: Rebanks, James
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: An interesting book describing the life of the Lake District shepherds. More after my Book Club discussion.It did remind me of passages (those involviAn interesting book describing the life of the Lake District shepherds. More after my Book Club discussion.It did remind me of passages (those involving sheep, shepherds and their dogs) of a book I read a very long time ago, "Crump Folk Going Home" by Constance Holme. When I got it out to have a look, I found that it is indeed set in Cumbria - what was then Westmorland - back in 1913. So of course I am now going to reread it.————In summary, I think the book is interesting in its descriptions of a particular way of life, one quite removed from my life experiences. The downside for me was Rebanks’ style, or lack of it. The writing is often pedestrian and occasionally dreadful. For example, he writes of pulling a book off the shelf “like it was a piece of junk”. Several times he uses the word disinterested when he means uninterested. A good editor should have dealt with such things.On the other hand, he has some lovely passages when he writes of the natural world. He observes the rooks in springtime as they pair up and make their nests:“They glide down from the wooded fell sides to where we feed without a single beat of their fingered wings, wheeling above us, seemingly motionless and within touching distance.”...more

title: A Month in the Country
author: Carr, J.L.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This book is without doubt one of the best, if not the best, that I shall read this year. It is exquisite: as delicate and beautiful as a spider's webThis book is without doubt one of the best, if not the best, that I shall read this year. It is exquisite: as delicate and beautiful as a spider's web bejewelled with raindrops.Tom Birkin, a damaged survivor of the Great War, comes to a village in Yorkshire to work on uncovering a fresco on the wall of the church. Gradually, as he uncovers what he finds to be a great work of art, his healing begins. He tells the story of what happened, looking back and remembering it as an idyll."Ah, those days ... for many years afterwards their happiness haunted me. Sometimes, listening to music, I drift back and nothing has changed. The long end of summer. Day after day of warm weather, voices calling as night came on and lighted windows pricked the darkness and, at day-break, the murmur of corn and the warm smell of field ripe for harvest. And being young.If I'd stayed there, would I always have been happy? No, I suppose not. People move away, grow older, die, and the bright belief that there will be another marvelous thing around each corner fades. It is now or never; we must snatch at happiness as it flies."Wonderful....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read "His Dark Materials" some years ago after reading a reference to the trilogy and being intrigued. I thought it was brilliant, and when I heard I read "His Dark Materials" some years ago after reading a reference to the trilogy and being intrigued. I thought it was brilliant, and when I heard that Pullman was returning to the story of Lyra, I wondered if he would be able to sustain that brilliance. Having now read "La Belle Sauvage", the first volume of his new trilogy titled "The Book of Dust", the answer is that yes, he has done so. I loved it, and look forward to reading the second volume (due out in October).The boy Malcolm makes the hero's journey, and does it with the help of Alice as they work together save and protect the baby Lyra. There are very real dangers to be overcome, and some dark moments with which they have to deal. While ostensibly written for children, these books have more than enough meat on them to keep adults very satisfied. They are not so much fantasy as the mythology of an alternate world. 4.5 stars....more

title: The Small Bachelor
author: Wodehouse, P.G.
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: For some reason, I have never read anything by P G Wodehouse before, and so started with this one on the recommendation of a friend. (Thank you Nancy!For some reason, I have never read anything by P G Wodehouse before, and so started with this one on the recommendation of a friend. (Thank you Nancy!)It was utterly delightful. I love the way that Wodehouse piles one absurdity on top of another, until the reader is almost helpless with laughter. All this, interspersed with sly digs at various individuals and groups. For example:"It was the sort of day when Tin Pan Alley lyric-writers suddenly realise that 'love' rhymes with 'skies above', and rush off, snorting, to turn out the song hit of a lifetime."And this:"He seemed to be deploring the get-rich-quick spirit of the modern girl, who is not content to sit down and wait for her alimony."By the time we reach the grand climax on the roof of our hero's apartment block, I was putty in Wodehouse's hands. At this point, George was hiding under the bed in his sleeping porch, which had become the hub of quite a lot of action:"A wave of self-pity flooded over George Finch. Why should he be so ill-used? He asked so little of Life, - merely to be allowed to lie quietly under a bed and inhale fluff: and what happened? Nothing but interruptions. Nothing but boots, boots, boots, boots, marching up and down again, as Kipling has so well put it. Ever since he had found his present hiding-place, the world had seemed to become one grey inferno of footsteps."Fortunately, it all comes right in the end, and the appropriate people head off to live happily ever after. Highly recommended....more

title: The Riddle of the Labyrinth: The Quest to Crack an Ancient Code
author: Fox, Margalit*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I love Ancient History, and I love puzzles and codes, so this book was a comfortable fit for me.The section I enjoyed the least was that dealing with I love Ancient History, and I love puzzles and codes, so this book was a comfortable fit for me.The section I enjoyed the least was that dealing with the work of Alice Kober, whom Fox wishes to push forward for recognition of all the work she did over many years on trying to decipher Linear B. Kober did indeed labour hard and long, and died in her forties, probably of some form of cancer. But Fox goes into too much forensic detail for a book presumably meant to appeal to people with a general interest in the subject, as opposed to those with an academic interest.The puzzle was solved by Michael Ventris, who did it with an intuitive leap quite alien to Kober’s way of working. I enjoyed the sections of the book devoted to him, and to Arthur Evans who found Knossos and the mysterious clay tablets, far more than the rather exhausting 100 pages or so dedicated to Alice Kober.An interesting examination of an extraordinary puzzle, and of the people who became obsessed with finding its solution....more

title: Doctor Thorne
author: Trollope, Anthony
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I never thought I would give Trollope only two stars. After the glories of "Barchester Towers", this third novel of the Barchester Chronicles was a grI never thought I would give Trollope only two stars. After the glories of "Barchester Towers", this third novel of the Barchester Chronicles was a great disappointment.The plot was so thin that it could all have been dealt with in 200 pages, but no, we went into every conversation and thought about the need for Frank to marry money for 800 wearying pages. I liked the character of Dr Thorne, who was a good and honourable man but human enough to become angry and impatient with the more impossible characters in the story. Frank was all right if a bit indecisive. Mary, his love interest, was sweet and pretty and nothing much else - almost a Dickensian heroine.Really, it isn't worth the effort. I do hope things pick up in the next part of the Chronicles, but I won't be checking it for a while yet....more

title: The Second Jungle Book
author: Kipling, Rudyard
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A reread after some 60 or more years! I read it and its predecessor because my book club read Neil Gaiman's "The Graveyard Book" this month, and I wasA reread after some 60 or more years! I read it and its predecessor because my book club read Neil Gaiman's "The Graveyard Book" this month, and I was interested to see how his tribute to Kipling had borrowed from the Mowgli stories. "The King's Ankus" is a very striking predecessor of the ancient tomb under the hill and The Sleer in Gaiman's book.Kipling's language is reminiscent of the King James version of the Bible. It gives all the animals a dignity that is sadly lacking in most modern stories with anthropomorphic animals. They are not cute: they kill to eat, they fight among themselves and with other species, and there is death. I had not remembered how powerful the stories were, and I can see why Gaiman wished to celebrate them....more

review: After rereading Josephine Tey’s book “The Daughter of Time” with my book club, I learned that it was this book which had inspired her to write her invAfter rereading Josephine Tey’s book “The Daughter of Time” with my book club, I learned that it was this book which had inspired her to write her investigation into the case of Richard III and the claim that he murdered his nephews and stole the English crown.It’s available from Project Gutenberg and well worth reading for anyone interested in the subject. As a firm supporter of Richard III as one of the more decent and honourable kings of England, I was of course biased in his favour. But Markham, while at times speculating on motives and feelings, has based his defence on a scrupulous assessment of the documents which have survived, and the known behaviours of the various major players.An interesting book about an endlessly fascinating subject....more
